Award.AbstractNarration:
The project follows up on a very exciting recent discovery: the potential detection of stellar mass black holes in an old globular cluster, using the NSF's Karl Jansky Very Large Array (VLA). Hundreds of stellar-mass black holes are expected to form in the early lifetimes of most clusters, and theoretical work suggests that these black holes quickly mass segregate to the cluster center and are nearly all ejected through mutual gravitational interactions. The existence of stellar-mass black holes in globular clusters would have broad implications: (i) globular clusters would become important hunting grounds for stellar-mass black holes, of which few are still known; (ii) globular clusters might offer a less biased view of the black hole mass function than the field; and (iii) the prospects for detecting gravitational wave sources such as black hole?black hole or black hole?pulsar binaries would be improved.

Discovery of additional black holes in other globular clusters with VLA would be highly significant, and require substantial re-assessment of our understanding of these clusters. The impact of finding an intermediate mass black hole in the survey of globular clusters would be very significant.

The broader impacts of this project focuses on three areas. The first is the inclusion of female undergraduates in research, starting early in their university careers. The second is the construction of new scientific exhibits focused on black holes and globular clusters for installation in a campus observatory. Finally, the broader scientific community and general public will be engaged in the results of ongoing research through social media interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most exciting recent discoveries was the detection of gravitational waves from the mergers of black holes.It is a theoretical puzzle as to how such systems form, since, in most models, a binary with two massive stars destinedto become black holes is either too close (and the stars merge before making black holes) or too distant (so thatboth stars become black holes, but do not ever merge and create gravitational waves over the lifetime of the universe).Hence it is a ``Goldilocks"-like problem.


A possible way of getting around this problem is to form the black holes separately and only later bring them together in a closebinary. This is vanishingly unlikely in the normal vastness of space, but there are a few special places where it could occur: one isin the center of a globular star cluster, a dense collection of millions of stars. Here, black holes that are born could lateracquire other black holes as companions in the dense center of the cluster.


The trouble with this idea was that, until very recently, there was very limited evidence for black holes in globular clusters,and indeed some astronomers had argued that globular clusters might lose their initial set of black holes, preventing the formation of binaries.The goal of this project was to look for evidence of black holes in globular clusters in our own Milky Way galaxy, using a totally newmethod: trying to find a glow at radio wavelengths that would only be visible if the black holes were actively eating gas, eitherfrom a companion star or from gas clouds in their immediate vicinity.


In this project we found evidence that black holes might actually becommon in globular clusters, with candidate black holesidentified in about a quarter of globular clusters that we studied. This shows that the formation of binaries containing two black holesmight indeed be common in globular clusters, and that this explanation for making gravitational wave sources is plausible.

We also used this project to help train undergraduate and graduate students in astronomy, and improve the exhibits at the local campus observatory.
